around Easter, it was agreed this week.Down Council is to push ahead with the opening arrangements following complaints that it has taken too long to get the prestigious project off the ground.Councillors have complained that a prime opportunity to publicise the park has been missed because it was not possible to hold an official opening when Ulster Television was filming in the district over St Patrickrsquos week.At the monthly council meeting it was also revealed that a businessman, who has opened a garden centre in Delamont, is annoyed because he was told the official opening would take place at Halloween last year.Mr John Cushnie opened his centre in July  and he claims he was given assurances by council officers that the park would officially open within four months.When the opening did not take place, Mr Cushnie went back to the councilrsquos recreation committee and only last month was told the opening ceremony would take place around St Patrickrsquos Day.Another businessman, who plans to open an exotic bird centre at Delamont, claims he has been kept waiting for firm proposals regarding the piece of land on which he needs to build the centre.ARDGLASS mdash District nursing sisters Philomena Hanna and Pauline McEvoy are continuing a tradition which dates back to the th century and Florence Nightingale.Butthe district nurse had her beginnings in Victorian Britain, she is very much a part of the late th century, having at her disposal all the skills and resources of the modern health service.Even sock there remains the fundamental commitment to the wellbeing of the community which inspired the founders more than  years ago. Based in Ardglass, Sisters Hanna and McEvoy carry on the tradition of combining the roles of nurse, friend and comforter.It was on the advice of Florence Nightingale, lsquoThe Lady With the Lamprsquo who sprang to national prominence for her pioneering work during the Crimean War, that a certain William Rathbone established the first training school for district nurses in .The aim was to educate women in all aspects of nursing care and therefore bring relief to the poor who were living in appalling conditions in the urban slums created as a consequence of the Industrial Revolution.By , there were  district nurses in the Liverpool area. As the benefits quickly became apparent, the service spread to other parts of Britain. The Queenrsquos Institute of Nursing set up its own training school and by  ndash when the National Health Service came into being ndash district nursing was available to  per cent of the population..prettyPhoto

title: Hinch whiskey now big tipple in Boston
story: ST Patricks Day revellers in Boston enjoyed locally produced Hinch Whiskey to celebrate Irelandrsquos patron saint.As Boston marked St Patrickrsquos Day for the first time since the global pandemic, Hinch Distillery near Ballynahinch was also celebrating as its brands were served for the first time in world famous bars in the city.Michael Morris, international sales director at Hinch Distillery, said: ldquoAt the centre of the action on St Patrickrsquos Day was world famous bars in Boston and we hosted a live feed on the day back to the distillery.ldquoThe Hinch International team was on hand to celebrate the brandrsquos launch in the Boston venues and help promote Hinch products at other venues in the city, the state and the national network.ldquoIt is hoped, with the brandrsquos prominence in Boston, it will be recognised as a new, serious player in what is the most important market for Irish whiskey in the world.He added: ldquoHinch Irish Whiskey has become a firm favourite locally and internationally. Itrsquos great that our distillery is open and expanding, and we can shout about the success our spirits have been making behind the scenes.St Patrickrsquos Day coincided with Hinch Distilleryrsquos recent win at the International Wine and Spirit Competition .This month the distillery also gained two prestigious Spirit Silver Awards for its Ninth Wave Gin and Ninth Wave Export Strength Gin.The accolades saw the gins receive  points and  points respectively, which is one of the highest scores that can be given to a product in the competition.Meanwhile, Hinch Irish Whiskey won the Small Company Product Category at the  Northern Ireland Food and Drink Awards, showcasing Northern Ireland food and drink companies.Hinch Distillery chairman, Dr Terry Cross OBE, said: ldquoWe have continued to develop our offering, expand our portfolio and win major deals in the shadows of what has been a very challenging economic climate..prettyPhoto

title: It’s the end of the road on Dancing for Matthew
story: IT was the last dance for Love Island star Matthew MacNabb on Sunday when he was voted off Dancing With The Stars Ireland.The  year-old Downpatrick man may not have made it to the final, but he found romance mdash something he failed to do on the top ITV dating show.He and professional dance partner Laura Nolanfinally confirmed their relationship with a kiss after they knew their time on the RTE show had come to an end.Matthewrsquos Samba mdash a notoriously dficult dance for celebrities mdashwas danced to One Dance by Justin Bieber.Scoring him  points, the judges were impressed by Matthewrsquos efforts.Brian Redmond remarked: ldquoMatthew, you know this might be a bit of a surprise. That actually wasnrsquot bad. Reverse samba rolls. You did move the hips, not perfect, bits still missing but it was very good.Loraine Barry said: ldquoWhen people hear samba they go, oh no, oh no.But I think you should both be very proud. Hips were moving. It was recognisable. Timing was there. Good rhythm, but still like you to work on your feet. For you this was a triumph.Arthur Gourounlian gushed: ldquoSo many facial expressions, you seem like you enjoyed it. Dancing wasnrsquot perfect. You were great in hold with Laura. You have improved so much over the weeks.After a short break, it was time for the Bust-A-Move Marathon, giving each couple a second chance to improve their scores.Matthew and Laura were the first couple to be asked to leave the dance floor, earning themselves just one extra point.Despite the heavy public vote that kept Matthew in the earlier rounds, he was up against singer Erica Cody in the dance-off.After the show, Matthew said: ldquoThis has been a rollercoaster,  hours a day, seven days a week. Irsquove grown so much. Laura is so talented and is an amazing person.He thanked Laura for ldquoteaching this rsquo lump with two left feet to dance.The couple were interviewed on RTEacutersquos Ryan Tubridy radio show on Monday morning Matthew admitted that he and Laura had a romantic connection straight away.ldquoShersquos so positive and so nice and kind to people. I just like [that] shersquos got such a love for le that I just resonated with straight away, he said.ldquoShersquos not afraid to go for things which is really admirable. To me I think in todayrsquos society, Laura is the kind of woman that young women should aspire to be like because shersquos strong, shersquos talented, she works hard and she doesnrsquot let anything get in the way of that.Laura said that neither she nor Matthew had expected anything romantic to have happened between them.ldquoIt was just a natural thing that happened between us. We got on so well. It wasnrsquot something I was expecting to happen when I came into the show, she said.ldquoIt just happened that as the weeks went on, we just really clicked as people and we really enjoy each otherrsquos company, so itrsquos just lovely."Matthew and Laura intend to travel to the United States for a well-earned break..prettyPhoto

title: Joseph Ferris Martial Arts students enjoy success at Dundonald Savate Open
story: STUDENTS from Joseph Ferris Martial Arts Academies recently successfully competed in the Dundonald Savate Open.The competition was hosted by Raptur Martial Arts at The Lair in the Inspire Business Park in Dundonald on February .There was a total of  fights and the clubs took  gold wins which was a brilliant achievement.Traditionally when the academies have a national or international competition, Su Joe presents the Jim Fettes Warrior Cup and trophy for the most inspirational junior and senior of the competition.The Jim Fettes Warrior Cup and Trophy is awarded in memory of local man, Jim Fettes.Jim was a great supporter of martial arts training.He believed that it had a positive impact on young people and the community as a whole.For this competition, Finn Carling from the Downpatrick academy was awarded the Junior Warrior Cup and Morgan Sandeman was awarded the Senior Warrior Trophy. Both awards were presented by Ashlinn Fettes, Jimrsquos daughter..prettyPhoto

title: Meeting over future of British Legion branch
story: A MEETING takes place tonight to decide the future of the Royal British Legionrsquos Downpatrick branch.Legion officials have arranged the meeting which takes place in the Parochial Hall at .pm, with news of the event coming just months after Legion officials warned that the future of the annual Remembrance Sunday parade in the town was in doubt due to declining membership.A number of current office-bearers have indicated that they are keen to retire from their current roles, prompting the decision to call next weekrsquos meeting to seenew members are willing to come forward.The branch chairman, Mr Andy Campbell, said the meeting has been called to find out what support there is from local people to get involved in the work of the organisation and ensure that thebranch continues to .ldquoWe are also keen to find out how many of our current members are prepared to carry on. None of us involved with the organisation would want to see it fold, he said.Mr Campbell said the meeting is open to everyone and is encouraging anyone interested in the work of the Royal British Legionrsquos Downpatrick branch to come along.ldquoWe are keen to hear from prospective new members, he said. Tonightrsquos weekrsquos meeting presents us with an opportunity to explore the level of interest in the community as we would like to see the branch continuing to .Ex-servicemen and women who live locally are being encouraged to get involved with the Downpatrick branch which several years ago was forced to close its base at Church Street with the building subsequently sold.Faced with dwindling numbers for the past number of years, the branch has decided to call the open meeting to see what the future holds.Mr Campbell added: ldquoI would encourage anyone with an interest in what we do to come along tonight. We need new members to help keep us going and hope there will be a positive response from the public..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle man receives life saving treatment
story: THE family of Newcastle man Alan McDonald is relieved that he has received the first dose of a potentially lesaving drug in New Zealand.They hope that itrsquos the first tentative step on the  year-oldrsquos road to recovery after having been diagnosed with a le-threatening disease.The -year-old, who lives near Christchurch with his fiancee, learnt over three weeks ago that he has aHUS, an extremely rare and potentially le-threatening disease which affects blood cells and causes damage to vital organs.While available on the NHS in the UK, the drug Eculizumab is not available in New Zealand.Due to the high cost of funding the drug infusions privately, the family launched a GoFundMe appeal last week, raising over pound,.Mr McDonaldrsquos mother Geraldine spoke of her familyrsquos hope for her sonrsquos condition to be stabilised in order for him to be flown back home to complete his treatment.She said: ldquoThe drug Alan needs arrived in New Zealand on Monday and he received his first infusion in the early hours of this morning. It is too early to say how he is responding, however we are hopeful that this is going to be a game changer in his recovery.ldquoAlan still has a long road ahead, but he is buoyed by the support from back home and has asked me to pass on his heartfelt thanks along with our own.Mrs McDonald said that aside from organising the funding appeal, her family felt helpless with her son being so far from home and family members not able to visit him.ldquoIt has been another tough week for Alan, as the medical team in Christchurch worked tirelessly to keep him stable with a series of procedures, including plasma exchange as well as regular dialysis. The treatment so far has already taken a toll on his body and, in Alanrsquos case, it is not having the outcome the medics had hoped for, she said.ldquoWersquove found it really dficult watching Alan go through all of this and not being able to be with him.ldquoThe distance between us back home and him in New Zealand feels even greater and we are desperate to see him again. We applied for visas to enter New Zealand on compassionate grounds three weeks ago but have had no confirmation or updates yet.Borders in New Zealand remain closed to oversea visitors as they prepare for the countryrsquos Covid- peak, but indications show they may reopen in May.Mrs McDonald said that her family has been overwhelmed by the generosity of people and their messages of support, but particularly the messages of hope they have received from people who have recovered from aHUS.ldquoFollowing our campaign to bring Alan home, many people reached out to share their experiences of either having aHUS or caring for a family member suffering from it, she said.ldquoThis has brought us so much comfort, hearing how others, especially those closer to home, have been through a similar situation and are through the other side, living their lives to the full again.The family is now exploring all the options to ensure Alan will have the necessary medical support to enable him to make the long journey home to Newcastle.They are working closely with the British Embassy, New Zealand Health Authorities and the local Health Trust in Northern Ireland in preparation for his arrival on Irish soil..prettyPhoto

title: Preserving our past
story: DOWN County Museum is currently threatened by plans to reduce and downgrade its staffing.Over many years high levels of community engagement and public support have enabled the Museum to build its collections.It is vital that the appropriate resources are deployed not only to care for and interpret the collections but also to maintain and develop links between the collections and the wider community.Take, for example, the museumrsquos photographic archive.Although the D J McNeill collection may be the best known and certainly the most extensive collection of photographs, the museum is responsible for the care and use of many more images.They represent all parts of County Down, of landscapes, towns and villages, inidual and group portraits, people at work, playing sport, historic events and everyday le.Two Men of Mourne was the title of a book published by Down County Museum in , based on photographs in the museum collection.The book highlights the work of two men who had spent many years photographing the Mournes and south Down.Pat Hudson, from Kilkeel, trained as a pharmaceutical chemist, but was a keen photographer ever since his early experience with a box Brownie camera.As an adult he captured the essence of the countryside he loved.His sister, Catherine, described his inquisitive and adventurous spirit which led Pat to leave Ireland in , first to work in an East African pharmacy.Then, after a short time in Jersey, he emigrated to Australia. After a briefto live in the south of England, Pat eventually settled in New Zealand where he spent the rest of his le.Patrsquos landscape photography is stunning and his portraits of local people are without parallel mdash they reveal a strong sense of place, identity and the character of the people.Particularly important is that most of the people have been identied.The photographs were mostly taken in the s and s, but since then the world has changed in many ways. Some of the landscapes may look the same, but buildings have gone, farming le is radically dferent and the fishing industry decimated.Cecil Newman grew up in Belfast, but from a young age enjoyed hiking and youth hostelling. He studied engineering at Queenrsquos University and joined the Royal Engineers during World War II.Whilst working in Berlin after the war to help with the processes of reconstruction, Cecil took some striking photographs of the devastated city. Some of these images were later given to the Berlin City Museum.After the war Cecil ed to work as surveyor for Belfast City Council and later as a planner in the Northern Ireland Civil Service. Amongst the many high-profile projects with which he was involved were the first Newry Area Plan and the Mourne Study. Both these publications included his photographs.During the s he concentrated particularly on aerial photographs. He was a leading member of the Ulster Society for the Preservation of the Countryside and Mournes Advisory Council, often giving talks illustrated with his photographs and slides. After his death the Ulster Society for the Preservation of the Countryside erected a memorial in his honour at Trassey car park in the Mournes.Photographs taken by him which are now in the Down County Museum collection reflect both his work and passion for the Mournes. An outstanding feature of Cecilrsquos photographs is that they were accompanied by date and Ordnance Survey map grid reference mdash what curator could ask for more The importance of these two photographic collections is that they complement each other, in covering the same geographical area, but taken for dferent purposes and at dferent times.The number of images represented is smaller than the DJ McNeill archive so it was possible for the museumrsquos curatorial staff to catalogue them all and the Museum Photographer to digitise them.What remains to be done is adding the images and full information to the Museumrsquos database and more to the website. There are always more jobs to be carried out on the collection.However, using the images effectively, and in the way the Hudson and Newman families, and indeed all other donors, wished, requires wide knowledge of all the collections by experienced and qualied professional staff working with them on a daily basis.The photographic archive is recognised as one of the most important in Ireland and contains a wide range of images, including daguerrotypes, glass negative plates, lantern slides, black and white and colour film, transparencies as well as digital images.Understanding of all the processes involved in their making is essential to how they are cared for and used.Lesley Simpson is secretary of the Friends of Down County Museum and former Keeper of Collections at the museum..prettyPhoto

title: Success at Downpatrick
story: PRIOR to Sundayrsquos Randox Ulster National Handicap Chase meeting at Downpatrick Racecourse, manager Richard Lyttle stated that he was looking forward to welcoming racegoers back to the track for the first time in three years.They certainly turned up with car parks filled to capacity, packed enclosures and long tailbacks on the Ballydugan Road prior to the first race.The Randox Ulster National has been the local tracks major race of the year now for many years and the maximum  runners faced the starter for the three mile four furlong race that sees prize money paid right down to the first six past the post.A bit like the big Aintree race, there was plenty of fallers with two coming down at the very first fence and Envoi Pierji then unseating Donegal jockey Conor Orr, who had ridden Screaming Colours to success for Bill Durkan in the Midlands National at Uttoxeter the previous day.Later in the race there was more fallers at the regulation fence.With two fences to be taken the race involved four runners with the  winner Amaulino travelling like the winner under David McGrath.But this combination then faded, eventually finishing fourth for Co Armagh trainer Keith Watson.The eventual winner in the famous J P McManus Silks proved to be Spades Are Trumps, ridden by Cheltenham winning jockey Mark McDonagh, a lb claimer.Finishing second was Agent Born, ridden by Darragh OrsquoKeefe with Peaches and Cream third.Co Meath trainer Gavin Cromwell, who also had success at Cheltenham, saddled the winner and also the third past the post. SP  ,  ,  .Portstorm, the locally trained favourite was a faller having started at  .The easiest and most popular winner of the day came in the Cosy Roof Bumper Race. Sir Jimmy Mac, with Downpatrick jockey Deckie Lavery in the saddle, was sent into the lead as the starter ped his flag and so well did the leader travel the newcomer was  s clear of the runner-up Rexem, ridden by Ben Harvey with Patrick Mullins only third on Tenzing.Patrick will soon miss seven days due to the suspension he received when getting Billaway up at the post to pip local hope winged leader in the Hunters Chase at Cheltenham.The winner was a first ever runner for owner Mrs Marie Laird of Bright and full marks to her husband Brian, well known in the pony racing world - he won a Dingle Derby - who did all the pre-training with the horse that was bred near Castlewellan by Brenda Cunningham. For Galway trainer Murdoch Kelly this was a welcome success. SP  ,  ,  ,The closest finish of the day came in the ever popular Boardsmill Sires Maiden Hunters Chase over two mile seven furlongs with only a short-head separating the first two past the judge.Handy Headon, with Oran McGill in the saddle, set out to make all in Ray Nicholas colours but after losing a shoe at the second last fence, was overtaken by Armagh winner McCaldinrsquos Faith Loving with Noel McParlan in the saddle.This partnership then lead over the final fence but on the climb to the post started to drt under pressure allow Handy Heaton back into it.However, along the rail came Michaelrsquos Pick to snatch a late victory over Handy Headon second, Faith Loving third, ahead of local Hope Tareeshal, the recent Tyrella winner.The winner is owned by former Westmeath trainer Dot Love and is trained by Ciaran Murphy at her former stables, his brother and twin Joe is a top event rider based outside Killyleagh. For winning rider, Dotrsquos grandson Timmy it was his second success under-rules, his first coming in a bumper back in . SP  ,  ,  fav.It was nice to see Alex Murdoch who rode many Hunter Chase winners at the track in a  year training and riding career, Alex sadly passed away last October at the age of .Featured on the race cardFirst race of the day, The Connollyrsquos Red Mills Maiden Hurdle, saw an awful start, that allowed Dromara owner trainer Neil McCluskeyrsquos I Donrsquot Get It poach a long lead.This lead looked sure to pay off for a long time until the latter stages when Barry Browne got the Oliver McKiernan trained Winding River past to win by three s.Long way back in third came Ben Crawford on The Flier Begley. SP  ,  ,  .There was a stewardrsquos enquiry into the start post race.Following the   and   winners at Down Royal we had another   winner when Jowaya Aoe and Ricky Doyle just get the better of Magic Sea, trained at Banbridge by Sarah Dawson in the closing stages of the WKD Handicap Chase. Back in third came Dferent Strokes. Gerry Keane trains the winner in Co Meath and this was his first National Hunt winner in sometime.The Tote Jackpot is back Handicap Hurdle saw Co Meath trainer John McConnell maintain his good recent track record when Andyrsquos Flame, ridden by Tyrone jockey Simon Torrens, just got up to snatch victory over the Peter Carberry ridden Sight Nor Seen with Dragons Pass third. SP  ,  ,  .Trainer Dermot Weld had another hurdle winner at the track when his Coitor ridden by Darragh OrsquoKeefe won the Toalrsquos Bookmaker race from Clondaw Hollow and Snugsborough Hall. SP  ,  ,  .While there was plenty of Northern owner trained and ridden horses placed at the St Patrickrsquos Day meeting at Down Royal, the only locally owned and trained winner came in the opening bluegrasshorsefeed Maiden Hurdle.The winner here proved to be Billable Grant but going by the SP of   the longest ever priced winner on a local track.Trained at Raffrey by Colin McBratney, the winner was a first winning ride by Gavin Brouder for the local trainer for whom this was a welcome change of fortune. For winning owner Pamela Ballantine it was a first success as an owner in her own colours.Saturday saw the loss of the Co Down Point-to-Point meeting at Loughbrickland following on from the loss of the recent North Down meeting and it has now been confirmed that the end of season meeting at Necarne has also gone.So after the Covid problems and also insurance issues the future looks bleak at present for owners etc with horses ready to run. This Saturday the Portrush meeting is due to take place and I believe the Co Down meeting will not be rearranged..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes are paid to Newcastle man and popular DJ
story: THE family and friends of much-loved U radio presenter and DJ Paul McKenna attended his funeral yesterday.The popular -year-old Newcastle man died last Wednesday at the Northern Ireland Hospice nearly two years after he was first diagnosed with cancer of the oesophagus.Friends from the world of broadcasting, including U presenters Frank Mitchell, Johnny Hero, and Carolyn Stewart and Q Radiorsquos Ibe Sesay, gave on-air emotional tributes to the father of three as the news of his untimely death rocked the entertainment world.He received the cancer diagnosis in June,  when a scan and tests revealed he also had it in his lung.While the cancer was successfully removed, it was followed by a year of chemotherapy treatment.However, Paul was told last year the cancer had ed. While devastated with the news, Paulrsquos we, Emma, said he was determined to beat the disease but only she knew that his condition was terminal.She spoke of his final moments and how his thoughts where of her and his daughters mdash Eimear, Rachel and Evie-Grace.ldquoHe asked me not to let the three girls forget him and he told me how much he loved me. He made me promise I would go to New York next year for my th birthday as thatrsquos where he had planned to take me, Emma told the Sunday Le.Emma described how Paul continued to try and fulfil his busy professional schedule, even going to DJ at an event four weeks ago with a syringe driver around his neck.ldquoPaul would never let anyone down,rsquorsquo said Emma. ldquoHe was still trying to help people.She said her husband only got to spend five nights in their new family home before needing hospice care.Paul, a former student of St Malachyrsquos High School, Castlewellan, started his radio career in Newcastle by helping out a friend with his mobile disco doing weddings. He got his chance to DJ on his own for the first time due to a double booking.He then began to DJ regularly at the Central Park nightclub in his early s, later securing a residency in The Groovy Train at the M Club in Belfast in .Paulrsquos break into radio came in  when he became a presenter with FM in Newry, part of the Q Radio Network, later becoming a breakfast presenter and eventually operations manager.He left in  and worked freelance for three years with Downtown Radio before joining U presenting the Sunday afternoon show in .In , he took on the overnight programme from midnight until am, Monday to Thursday.Paul also was a multi-award winning wedding DJ and played regularly as the recommended DJ for the Hastings Hotel Group.OrsquoHares in Newcastle paid its condolences on social media to Paulrsquos family and friends:: lsquoDJ PK was a resident here for many years and was heavily involved in the success of Central Park and Coast nightclub entertaining generations of party goers here.rsquoAfter a service at Our Lady Of The Assumption Church in Newcastle, Paulrsquos remains left for cremation in Dardistown Crematorium in Dublin..prettyPhoto

title: Volunteers urged to sign up for important service
story: A SAINTFIELD man is helping to tackle the problem of loneliness experienced by older people.Recent statistics show that more than one in three people in Northern Ireland are more often lonely, and chronic loneliness affects around one in  people.For thousands of people across Northern Ireland with loneliness, Volunteer Now is keen to raise awareness of the wide range of services freely available to anyone experiencing loneliness or living in isolation, such as Age NIrsquos Check In and Chat Service.Saintfield man Stevie Lee mdash a writer currently working on his third novel mdash is a volunteer for Age NIrsquos Check In and Chat service.He explained: ldquoI lost my mum to dementia around  years ago and my dad now lives in sheltered housing. Hersquos  and I only get to see him once a week.ldquoI was thinking about how important those visits are to him and I knew I wanted to help others experiencing loneliness so I volunteer, I thought I could give an hour a week, no problem, said Stevie.ldquoThere were a lot of opportunities available, but I really liked the sound of the Age NI Check In and Chat service, where volunteers are matched with older people experiencing isolation or loneliness for a regular weekly phone chat.By signing up to volunteer with Age NI, Stevie was connected to John , who lives alone in Bangor.John has lived on his one for a very long time after losing his we when she was very young.He told of how Steviersquos regular phone calls with him as proved to be a leline during the pandemic.ldquoCovid just made things so much worse. I felt incredibly lonely and isolated without my regular routine, said John.ldquoLoneliness is very hard to live with. We all need connection and it was really affecting me, so Irsquom so glad I found help and really look forward to my weekly phone call with Stevie.ldquoStevie is a great friend and a real breath of fresh air. I look forward to his calls all week. Itrsquos very comfortable and easy. Hersquos very kind and I always feel I can tell him anything.I feel very good for it, just having someone to talk to.Stevie said of his connection with John: ldquoAs soon I got on the phone with John, I knew it was a great match. We got on well and we had lots of things in common, so it was really easy to chat. For the first month or so he always thanked me for calling. Now, itrsquos like ringing a mate, itrsquos really natural. We have great chats and sometimes itrsquos hard to get a word in.ldquoI know he spends a lot of time alone and the move to a new home and new neighbours has been hard on him at his stage in le. Hersquos getting really settled now, though, and is starting to open up a bit and get to know some new people.Stevie said that he has gained a lot too from being introduced to John.ldquoHersquos also been a great source of inspiration for me mdash I chat to him about my writing and we bounce ideas around. I think he really enjoys the opportunity to flex his imagination and he has some completely dferent ideas, which is brilliant mdash we can chat for hours about stories, he said.ldquoJohn has been on his own for a long time and I know hersquos been through some really tough times with his mental health. He has been very open with me, and I think wersquore good for each other explains Stevie.Stevie is encouraging others to consider volunteering to provide such an easy but important human connection to a lonely older person.ldquoTo anyone considering volunteering, I would say go for it straight away. If yoursquore the sort of person who cares about other people, itrsquos not costing you anything and it gives you happiness to know yoursquore helping someone, when you realise how thankful they are such a small act. Itrsquos also allowed me to make a new friend in John, and for that Irsquom truly grateful, added Stevie.Volunteer Now is also urging anyone interested in volunteering to try it out. Through Volunteer Nowrsquos online volunteering  mdash volunteernow mdash volunteers can be matched to find local activities that best suit their skills, passions and interests. Those interested can also chat to a Volunteer Now team member for support and information.Jane Gribbin, community engagement manager at Volunteer Now, said: ldquoThe pandemic has signicantly decreased our volunteer numbers and the reality is that without volunteers, many important services which people rely on simply couldnrsquot exist.ldquoVolunteers are the leblood of Northern Ireland and their amazing work has transformed the lives of so many people here.ldquoI would encourage anyone with time to spare or an interest in helping others to visit our online volunteering  at volunteernow, register your interest and give volunteering a go. With hundreds of unique volunteering opportunities on offer, itrsquos a fantastic way to expand your skills, try something new and give back to your community.For more information visit www.volunteernow..prettyPhoto

title: Washed up munitions a reminder of Murlough’s military history
story: THE news of a controlled explosion on Murlough beach last Thursday might sound shocking.But it isnrsquot the first time that Army bomb disposal experts have detonated a suspected WWII mortar found in County Downrsquos sands.Such ordnance washes up relatively frequently, assumed to have escaped the Beaufort Dyke trench in the Irish Sea, where massive amounts of munitions were dumped after the war mdash including  tons of four-inch mortars.But stray munitions have also been found before in Murloughrsquos sand dunes, reflecting the arearsquos rich wartime history.In fact, Murlough Nature Reserve mdash formerly known as the Dundrum Sandhills mdash has interesting history that extends far beyond WWII.The name itself comes from the old Irish word lsquoMuirbolcrsquo, meaning lsquosea-bagrsquo , and evidence of human activity in the -acre reserve extends back to around  BC.Archaeological digs in the s unearthed multiple signs of burning, hundreds of pottery shards, worked flints and even carbonised hazelnut shells that confirm Neolithic and Bronze Age activity.Much later, Murloughrsquos dunes were important for the Normans. They were used as a commercial rabbit warren when John De Courcy arrived and built Dundrum Castle in .The lucrative trade in rabbit pelts continued for centuries afterwards. Rabbits are still common today, although the population was decimated by the myxomatosis disease in the s.The s was also when the National Trust began managing the habitat on behalf of its owners, the Hill family mdash commonly known as the Marquises of Downshire.The Hill family came to the area in the late th century but had lived in Ireland since the late s, when a young army officer named Moyses Hill, originally from Devon, was posted to Carrickfergus garrison in  to command forces sent by Elizabeth I to subdue the rebellious OrsquoNeill clan and colonise Ireland.Moyses ended up staying in Ireland and marrying the sister of a local clan chief. In , he was granted land at Cromlyn, an area which later took his surname and became known as Hillsborough. His descendants then acquired Murlough in  and began using Murlough Farm as their summer residence.They built Murlough House in , which still stands today at the end of Keel Point mdash at the northern end of the beach. While built to have a spectacular sea view, stormy weather kept breaking the windows, so trees were planted around the house in , and the woodland remains to this day.In , the th Marquis of Downshire, Arthur Hill, sold the surrounding land to the National Trust and then sold the house in . The area became Irelandrsquos first nature reserve in  and remains the most extensive dune heath in Ireland .But prior to being sold to the National Trust, Murlough House and the dunes were a hotbed of military activity ndash particularly during WWII. The house was a base for the US Armyrsquos st Armoured Division and the th Tank Destroyer Battalion.They built several firing ranges in the dunes, including, allegedly, a mortar range. Spare bombers and fighters were also hidden there as Murlough Farm had its own landing strip, called lsquo Satellite Landing Groundrsquo .Murlough beach itself was dotted with anti-aircraft and anti-invasion posts mdash whose rotting remnants are still visible today. They were dug-in when a full-scale German invasion was a threat in the early s.They were part of a counter-invasion strategy that centred on slowing or stopping the enemy at certain locations until other forces could be mustered and deployed. This involved constructing a so-called lsquocoastal crustrsquo along beaches and inland lsquostop-linesrsquo along rivers, canals and high ground.With Northern Ireland being prime invasion territory, a coastal crust was set up from Magilligan in the north-west to Newcastle in the south-east, alongside an inland stop-line along the route of the River Bann. Anti-aircraft landing posts, like those at Murlough, were important in preventing aircraft or boats from landing, but another type of defence was the centrepiece of this strategy: pillboxes.When events at Dunkirk in  sparked invasion panic, the Directorate of Fortications and Works at the War Office was created to construct defensive systems around the UKrsquos beaches. The Royal Engineers and civilian contractors erected over , pillboxes by in a matter of days ndash including on eight of Northern Irelandrsquos beaches.Such structures can still be seen at Magilligan, Portrush and Portstewart. County Down also has intact examples in Bangor, Donaghadee and on the Strangford shore between Comber and Newtownards. Beaches at Minerstown and Tyrella also had multiple pillboxes, as did Murlough. They were spaced to have interlocking arcs of fire, so invaders had little unchallenged space in which to land.One of these pillboxes is still visible in Newcastle, on the beach just below the outdoor swimming pool. The remnants of the other are still visible at the northern end of Murlough, next to the inlet that feeds Dundrum Bay. Yet all that is left are large slabs of reinforced concrete as this pillbox was supposedly destroyed in the early days of the Troubles to prevent it being used to attack the nearby Ballykinlar Army Camp.But these remains are now also under attack from erosion. They are gradually being absorbed by the sea. With this stretch of coastline losing five to ten metres of coastline a year, the remnants of the pillbox, originally built at an elevated height in the dunes, is even starting to be submerged at high tide.What was once a reflection of an indominable spirit is now an unassuming pile of rubble used only as a seat for resting walkers ndash most of whom are unaware of its history. Soon, it will be completely forgotten and the only reminder of this stretch of coastlinersquos rich military history will be the occasional washed-up ordnance.Ben Acheson spent seven years deployed to Afghanistan, including stints as Director of NATOrsquos political team and as Political Adviser to the EU Special Representative. His first book, Wolves Among Men: The Pashtun Tribes in Afghanistan, is due to be published later this year..prettyPhoto

title: raise a glass of rum to our nuclear submariners keeping uk safe from putin
story: Irish League football legend David Jeffrey ‘giving up the day job’   Mothers Day : When is Mother’s Day  Why is the date dferent in the UK and why does it change every year NewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionRaise a glass of rum to our nuclear submariners keeping UK safe from PutinA letter from J T Hardy:By The NewsroomMonday, th March , : pm  "       "  Letter to the editorCampaign for Nuclear Disarmament are not enjoying a high media profile these days as the war in Ukraine painfully grinds on. The deadly consequences for combatants and civilians, plus economic pain across the wider world, are the subject of frequent news updates. Maybe we should all be raising a glass of porterto the Royal Navy submariners in Trident submarines. Wherever they are, somewhere between the North Pole or South Pole and the equator, it’s good to know that Vladimir Putin will be disinclined from ever launching an attack on the UK or other NATO countries.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.A great le lesson for younger people is being spelt out: evil forces are all too real and bullies need to be confronted. That’s also the message of the Easter Cross when we open the Bible: “And having spoiled principalities and powers, he made a shew of them openly, triumphing over them in it.”Evil powers and principalities most definitely exist in our disordered world and that’s why we need a Royal Navy. It was possibly never any dferent, though, when we consider these words attributed to King Charles the Second : “It is upon the navy under the good Providence of God that the safety, honour, and welfare of this realm do chiefly depend.”J T Hardy, Belfast——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: were peaceful and law abiding unionists not rabble rousers
story: Homes evacuated after suspicious object discovered at NI train station   UUP leader Doug Beattie concedes he will lose votes after pulling out of anti-protocol ralliesNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionWe’re peaceful and law-abiding unionists – not rabble-rousers!A letter from two leading loyal order members:By Roy Ferguson and David MartinTuesday, th March , : pm  "       "  An online flyer for the rally - which has Mr Beatties face and name on itLurgan United Unionists is a grassroots movement comprising local loyalists from across the Orange Institution, the Royal Black Institution, the Apprentice Boys of Derry, and several marching bands, united in a common cause: the defence of our place within the United KingdomIn furtherance of this, from the outset we’ve recognised that unionism is far stronger united than ided. It was in this context that we seek to bring together all sections of political unionism at a protest rally to be held in Lurgan on Friday, April .The purpose is to demonstrate a united unionist front, with all sections of political unionism standing shoulder-to-shoulder with grassroots loyalists and unionists in opposition to the protocol.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Letter to the editorUnfortunately one of those who had agreed to attend, Doug Beattie, has chosen to withdraw, and thereby isolate himself from his own constituents and the wider Unionist family who are uniting around the common cause of destroying the protocol and saving the Union.Mr Beattie cites as a reason for his withdrawal from anti-protocol rallies his belief that they are harnessing anger and increasing tensions.To suggest that the protest rallies are anything other than a peaceful and dignied expression of loyalist opposition to the protocol is an egregious slur upon those who have organised, attended, and addressed such events. Our organisation comprises members of the loyal orders and local bands, many of whom it must be noted served with distinction in the security forces over  years to defend this province from republican terrorism.We are not rabble rousers out to increase tension. Rather we are law abiding, peaceful and loyal citizens.We would call upon Mr Beattie to publicly apologise for his comments which, whether he intended it or not, have besmirched the name and reputation of our organisation, the loyal orders, and thousands upon thousands of loyal Ulstermen who have taken to the streets to exercise their democratic and legitimate right to peacefully protest against the imposition of this protocol for which they did not vote and to which they do not consent.Mr Beattie has failed to explain how his strategy of negotiating with the EU while at the same time implementing the protocol via the Assembly will ever result in the destruction of the protocol.Negotiation by its very nature results in agreement and compromise. Unionism cannot compromise on this issue. Unionism cannot accept anything less than the complete destruction of the protocol.We call on all of our fellow loyalists across Ulster to join with us on April  in sending a clear message to all of our opponents that we will never accept a border in the Irish Sea and that we will never be part of a process designed to ease Ulster into a united Ireland. No surrender.Roy Ferguson, President, Apprentice Boys of Derry David Martin, District Master, Lurgan District No For more political news, click here:WATCH: Crowd cheers for the destruction of the  Belfast Agreement at loyalist rally Bryson dubs Simon Coveney a ‘meddling aggressor’ saying the Dublin government ‘swans around NI asthey own the place’——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: special event to celebrate the very best of rory best
story: UVF row: ‘Ignoring peaceful protests undermines loyalist leaders’ says LCC after Simon Coveney security alert   Rathcoole: Two men arrested in murder investigation after body found in waterNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPeopleSpecial event to celebrate the very best of Rory BestUlster and Ireland legend Rory Best is to be honoured with special celebration evening hosted by his home club.By Graeme CousinsTuesday, th March , : pm  "       "  Banbridge Rugby Club has organised the black-tie event in the Europa Hotel to not only mark the phenomenal achievements of the retired Ireland captain, but to boost fundraising for the club’s ‘Club for All’ development project.‘A Celebration of Rory Best’ will take place on the evening of Wednesday, May .Rory retired at the end of  and the club planned on celebrating his achievements then, but COVID- put paid to those plans. Now that the event is back on, the club and its members are excited to finally get the opportunity to celebrate one of their own.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply., Joy Mawson Rebecca Baker . The Rory Best celebration evening aims to raise money for Banbridge RFCs Club for All projectand Cancer Fund for Children." "" width"" srcset"https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMNjYyMTUx.jpg width w, https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMNjYyMTUx.jpg width w" layout"intrinsic" class"i-amphtml-layout-intrinsic i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"intrinsic", Joy Mawson Rebecca Baker . The Rory Best celebration evening aims to raise money for Banbridge RFCs Club for All projectand Cancer Fund for Children." fallback layout"responsive" "" width"" src" img placeholder.png" class"i-amphtml-layout-responsive i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"responsive"Rory Best pictured along with representatives from Banbridge Rugby Club’s girls youth team, Victoria Cromie , Joy Mawson Rebecca Baker . The Rory Best celebration evening aims to raise money for Banbridge RFCs Club for All projectand Cancer Fund for Children.Banbridge RFC President Maynard Sinton said: “As Rory took up mini rugby at Banbridge at the age of six, we’ve considered him one of our own for over  years. Now that he has retired, it feels like the right time to celebrate his achievements and we’re thrilled that he’s given us his support to push forward with our redevelopment plans.”Rory’s chosen charity, Cancer Fund for Children, will also benefit from the event. In September , Rory took on a mammoth challenge to help children across Ireland cope with the impact of cancer diagnosis. He walked  miles from Daisy Lodge, Co Down to the site of Cancer Fund for Children’s new short break centre in Mayo raising over £,, in the process.Rory Best said: “I couldn’t be prouder to work with my home club on this event. “I have had unwavering support from club members and the local community in my rugby career which means so much to me and I am delighted that I can give something back and be involved in a project which will open up opportunities in rugby to many more people from all backgrounds.“It’s an exciting time for the club as it looks to the future and I’m delighted to be able to support such a great cause”.The black-tie event will feature a host of Rory’s former playing colleagues in a series of not-to-be missed QA sessions. They will discuss their time playing with and against him as well as the upcoming Ireland tour of New Zealand and the Rugby World Cup next year. Cancer Fund for Children CEO Phil Alexander commented: “Cancer Fund for Children is proud to call Rory Best our ambassador. “Not only has he waved the flag for childhood cancer he has also raised vital funds that will help ensure children and young people impacted by cancer receive the emotional and therapeutic support they need.” For more information and to purchase a table for the event email [email#protected]——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: sports direct reveals uks loved sports teams including arsenal chelsea
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe sports retailer analysed teams associated with leagues across eight sports from up and down the country and crafted a list based on a number of critical factors.The researchers looked at everything from the teams brand sentiment on social media to its number of online searches.The ranking was also constructed by looking at online mentions, social following and fan engagement.Sports Direct store. Credit: PA "Sports Teams are the bread and butter of the sporting world," the sportswear brand said.It added: "They matter immensely to fans and to iniduals themselves, but which ones are the most loved across the UK "                                                                                                              : Six Nations referees  - meet the refs assigned to every game: Winter Olympics: Triumphant curling teams land in Scotland                                                                                                              Sports Direct has rounded up the UKs most popular sports and its definitely an interesting mix.Most Loved Sports. Credit: Sports Direct Unsurprisingly, Football tops the list with an average of ,, loves on social media, the retailer has confirmed.Coming in second and third is Rugby League and Union respectively and rounding up the ranking is Athletics.FootballRugby LeagueRugby UnionIce HockeyCricketNetballRowingAthleticsDid you know that you can shop by sport on the Sports Direct websiteIf youre looking for gear and equipment to try out a new sport, youll find all the kits you could possibly need in the ious sports categories on its website. Whether youre a running rookie or youre nuts about the NFL, Sports Direct can keep you right. .removeShop the collection via the Sports Direct website.Top  sports in the UK. Credit: Sports Direct Sports Direct has crafted its top  list and we arent surprised to see Football dominate the top  spots of the most popular sports teams in the UK. However, youll find other sports teams in the ranking this year with beloved Ice Hockey, Rugby Union, Netball and Athletics making the top  list. You can see the full breakdown of the sports team rankings via the Sports Direct website which includes fan favourites like Cricket and Rowing too.Arsenal - FootballLiverpool- FootballCha - FootballMan City - FootballWest Ham - FootballCardf Devils - Ice HockeyGloucester - Rugby UnionShaftesbury Barnett Harriers - AthleticsGuildford Flames - Ice HockeyHarlequins - Rugby UnionNorthampton Saints - Rugby UnionSaracens - Rugby UnionTeam Bath Netball - NetballLeicester Tigers - Rugby UnionWoodford Green and Essex Ladies - AthleticsFootball fans can shop for their teams kits and wear strips from some of the countrys biggest teams including Manchester United, Newcastle United, Tottenham Hotspur and more.Meanwhile, Rugby Union fans can sports strips from Wales, England and Scotland by picking one up from the Sports Direct website.

title: six nations cardiff bus diversions wales v france italy
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThere will be bus ersion from .pm on Friday, March  – when Wales take on France – and between .am and .pm on Saturday, March , when Wales play Italy.Bus users are also being advised that there will be some changes to normal match day stops, along with route ersions.Services  and  and  will start and end at Canal Street. Services  and  will not serve the rear of Central Railway Stationfrom the time roads are closed until the end of service.The Baycar service  will start and end at the Customhouse Streetonly and will not serve the rear of Central Railway Station from the time the roads close until the end of service.Services , , A, and X towards Cardf Bay and the Sports Village will start and end at Hayes Bridge Road.Services , , , , , , , ,  , , , , , ,   and A will start and end at Fitzhamon Embankment.Services , ,  and  will start from Greyfriars Road GN .Services , , A and  will start from a temporary bus stop on Kingsway, opposite Friary Gardens.Services , ,  will start and end at Greyfriars Road.Services  and  to the Heath Hospital, , , , , , , ,  and Xwill start and end at Churchill Way. Commercial director at Cardf Bus, Gareth Stevens, said:“To accommodate road closures and to ensure travel can continue without too much disruption, we’ve introduced ersions in the city centre when Wales’ Six Nations matches are played at home here in Cardf.“We would advise all our customers to check these route changes before travelling on match days to ensure they are fully informed on the ersions in place.”For more information visit www.cardfbus principality-stadium

title: penarth art fair set summer
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe fair had been cancelled for the past couple of years due to the pandemic, but willin July this year.The event will take place at Penarth Pavilion from from Friday, July , to Sunday, July .So far, nine local artists, sculptors and galleries have booked stands at the fair, as well as the Queen Street Gallery from Neath.Of those who have booked stands, two are Penarth-based artists Nia Bennett and Sasha Kingston.Other artists from Cardf, Ogmore, Pontypridd and Llantwit Major will also be attending.Only three spots are left at the fair, which is being advertised as a good networking opportunity for artists.Michael Goode, the event organiser, said: "I am very pleased with the response from local artists, sculptors and galleries to sell their work directly to the public in the unique setting of the Penarth Pier Pavilion."It means that I now have only three stands available, so please get in touchyou want more information."To find out more information, contact info@inc-creative.wales. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: last minute tickets cheltenham festival    buy
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityTickets are highly coveted, which can be seen in the fact that they are already sold out for Day Three and Four of the event, with a week still to go before it all kicks off.However, for those still wanting to see some of the action, there are tickets still left for Day One and Two.Heres where you can find them.ONE WEEK TODAY. 😮This noise... pic IOaoBCHQZ— CheltenhamRacecourseMarch , How to get tickets for Cheltenham Festival Day OneFor Day One tickets are still available for the Best Mate enclosure which offers "an atmosphere like no other" according to the Jockey Club websiteIt has great views for the racing as it is directly opposite the main grandstand and adjacent to the finish line.Prices for the Best Mate enclosure start at £ and can be found on the Jockey Club website hereMeanwhile, there is also still some availability for the Tattersalls enclosure, which is a middle point between the club and the Best Mate enclosure.Tickets for this area are priced from £ and cane be found on the Jockey Club website hereBefore there was TIGER ROLL, there was BALTHAZAR KING 👑️⃣ @Glenfarclas Cross Country wins️⃣ Cheltenham wins pic NQzXeaIEk— CheltenhamRacecourseMarch , Day TwoTickets are avaiulable for the Best Mate enclosure from £ and the Tattersalls enclosure from £ on Day Two.Additionally, tickets are also available for the Club enclosure on this day, at a slightly higher cost of £ or more.All of these can be found on the Jockey Club website here

title: m a road closures around newport cardiff swansea week
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityOvernight closures will impact ious parts of the motorway around Newport, Cardf and Swansea.These are the sections of the M and A that will be disrupted by road closures this week.M and A road closures in Wales this weekM westbound, junction : The westbound carriageway of the M will be closed between the Prince of Wales Bridge and junction  for Rogiet this week. Maintenance work will close the road overnight on Monday and Tuesday. Closures will be in place between pm and am each evening to allow maintenance work to take place on the section of motorway.A westbound, M, junction  – Cross Hands: The A will be closed overnight throughout this week and into next to allow resurfacing work to take place. The road will be shut between the M at junction  for Pont Abraham and Cross Hands. The resurfacing week is ongoing for more than two weeks forcing overnight closures on the section of westbound carriageway. Closures will be in place between pm and am each evening. title: penarth weather forecast
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityUnfortunately for those ready to get out the shorts, this week is predicted to be cooler according to the Met Office. There is some good news though, with the fact that it is predicted to be another mainly dry week.Wind chill means that the temperature is set to feel around three to four degrees cooler than the highs predicted by the Met Office.Here we look at the week’s weather forecast for Penarth:Monday:Monday is set to be the last hurrah for the warm temperatures we experienced last week as the Met Office predicts temperatures will be as high as  degrees today. Unlike last week’s sun, it is set to be cloudy for most of the day but remain dry.The Met Office predicts sunny intervals around midday and pm.Tuesday:Tuesday’s temperature is set to reach  degrees at its highest around pm. It is expected to be cloudy but with sunny intervals throughout most of the day.Wednesday:Wednesday is set to be the odd one out as it is a cloudy day with showers forecast for most of the afternoon and evening. Temperatures are set to reach highs of  degrees.MORE NEWS:Thursday:Thursday is set to be a mixed bag of cloudy and sunny spells throughout the day. Temperatures are set to reach highs of seven degrees.Friday:Temperatures are set to rise slightly on Friday with highs of nine degrees. It is predicted to be a mix of sunny in the morning, with clouds rolling in from around pm onwards. There will still be some sun according to the Met Office throughout most of the afternoon, although it will be in intervals.Saturday:Saturday is set to see high temperatures of around nine degrees. Sunny intervals are predicted for most of the morning, before it turns to a cloudy afternoon and evening. Some sunny intervals are predicted for parts of the afternoon..removeSunday:Sunday is predicted to see some sun in the morning but changing to cloudy in the afternoon with the occasional sunny interval. Temperatures are set to reach highs of  degrees. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIf you need a few more ideas then Groupon might be able to help with a number of discounts and offers on ious experiences.They are all suitable for family groups so they should be enough to keep people from ious age groups entertained.A selection of what is available from Groupon can be found below.April experiences available through GrouponUpside Down HouseInstagram-worthy: Upside Down House in Brighton has visitors snapping selfies pic suDnkrwU— ReutersJune , Up to six visitors can walk Lakeside locations,  per cent off at Brighton and  per cent off at Westfield London and Milton Keynes.Get the discount for this at the Groupon website hereWith up to  dferent locations to choose from, title: penarth flat cheapest sale area almost
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe flat is the cheapest currently available to buy in Penarth"   The cheapest property currently for sale in Penarth for almost £,The open plan living dining kitchen area is the centrepiece of the flat"   The cheapest property currently for sale in Penarth for almost £,The kitchen area is modern and has room for dining table"   The cheapest property currently for sale in Penarth for almost £,The bedroom is spacious and has room for a double bed"   The cheapest property currently for sale in Penarth for almost £,The bathroom has been redurbished recently"   The cheapest property currently for sale in Penarth for almost £,Occupants have access to the rear garden with extra storage outside"   Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"THE cheapest property that isnt a retirement flat in Penarth on Rightmove is currently on sale for just under £,.According to the UK Land Registry data, the average flat price in the Vale of Glamorgan was £, in January.The price of this one bedroom flat on Harriet Street in Cogan was reduced in January so that the asking price is now £,.The property includes one double bedroom, an open plan living kitchen dining area, a bathroom and a garden.Recommended for a first time buyer, the property listing also advertises a good amount of storage space, as well as double-glazed windows.The open plan living kitchen dining area contains a grill combination microwave as well as a split level oven, hob, washing machine and dishwasher.There is also a breakfast bar and plenty of space for a table and chairs in the modern kitchen area.The bedroom is spacious for a one bedroom flat and, like the rest of the property apart from the bathroom, has wooden flooring.The newly refurbished bathroom contains a rainfall shower with minimal shower screen, a toilet with twin flush, and has hidden plumbing throughout.There is a south facing rear garden, with raised beds and lawn, decking and outside storage.The first floor flat has access to the garden for drying clothes and to the parking area on the left hand side.Parking is available for two cars at the front of the property and this is where occupants can access the gas meter.Council tax costs £,. per annum as it is a Band C property.To find out more, visit the listing on Rightmove here

title: petition save outdoor seating penarth started
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe petition calls for the Vale of Glamorgan Council to backtrack on plans to remove the seating which was installed during the pandemic in order to help businesses.Traders on the Esplanade were given notice that they must remove the seating by June  this year, as the licence to have the seating ends then.The seating currently blocks an extra  car parking spaces, though some have said this is a small price to pay for adding vibrancy to the Esplanade.However, others argue that the extra parking is needed as most bays are often full, especially during the summer.The Welsh Government recently proposed that some of the seating on land adjacent to hospitality venues could remain without the need for further planning permission.The consultancy for this proposal ended on February .The petition, started by Jemma Angove, states: "The outdoor seating area was a welcome addition to the Esplanade".It also claims the move will encourage people to drive, conflicting with the Vale of Glamorgan Councils goal to achieving net zero status.The petition asks the Vale of Glamorgan Council to reconsider this move in light of the public reaction.:A commenter on the petition said: "I’ve never seen the sea front so busy, so obviously there’s no need for more parking."Leave the sea front as it is, so people can continue to enjoy it and support local traders."Another commented: "Its good to see people enjoying themselves on the sea front."A move back to parking would be a backward step."At the time of writing, the petition has gained , signatures in a few days.To view the petition, click hereThe Vale of Glamorgan Council has been contacted for comment. article_url   content_id   site_id title: m s easter eggs  range including harry potter percy pig
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe brand has a mix of classic chocolate eggs to luxury but affordable eggs and even Harry Potter-themed treats. Along with the traditional Easter Egg, there is also the hunt bags that have everything you need to create the perfect and most memorable EasterBeat the crowds and see the full MS Easter collection." alt"Penarth Times: Belgian Milk Chocolate Floral Easter Egg. " class"editor-image"Belgian Milk Chocolate Floral Easter Egg.Created by the brands own skilled chocolatiers, this Collection egg is crafted from smooth Belgian chocolate and hand-decorated with sugar flowers. You can get this luxurious Easter Egg delivered straight to your door for just £ via the MS website. " alt"Penarth Times: Percy Pig Easter Egg Hunt Gt Bag. " class"editor-image"Percy Pig Easter Egg Hunt Gt Bag.If youre a Percy Pig fan then look no further as MS has all the Easter Percy you could need with the Hunt Gt Bag. The gt bag includes two Percy Pig penny bags, Percy and Penny Hogs and Kisses, Easter Party Percy, Percy Pig Sweets, Percy Pigs Easter Egg Hunt kit, and Percy Pig Online Exclusive gt bag. You can get the gt bag now for £ via the MS website. " alt"Penarth Times: MS Harry Potter Golden Egg Tin. " class"editor-image"MS Harry Potter Golden Egg Tin.MS has made the perfect Easter Egg for Harry Potter fans inspired by the treasured Golden Snitch.With a flavourful white chocolate hollow egg featured in a hand-finished shimmer tin that features designs inspired by Hogwarts. You can get it now for £ via Ocado. " alt"Penarth Times: Chicky Choccy Treats Easter Letterbox gt. " class"editor-image"Chicky Choccy Treats Easter Letterbox gt.If you cant be with your loved ones this Easter but still want to send them some love, then its Easter Letterbox gt is perfect.The gt includes four bubbly bunnies, a Chicky Choccy Speckled Eggs, a net of Choccy Eggs, a net of Caramel Eggs, two orange speckled eggs, milk choc corn. You can get it now for £ via MS.To shop the full Easter Range head to the Marks and Spencers website.

title: major changes recycling penarth dinas powys
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMajor changes to recycling have already been made in Barry and rural parts of the Vale of Glamorgan, with separate containers used for dferent materials.As a new recycling plant is set to open in Barry later this year, these changes are almost ready to roll out to the eastern parts of the Vale in October.Vale of Glamorgan council, which has the second best recycling rate in Wales, has set out a plan for the next decade on how to increase recycling rates further.Peter King, cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, said the Vale’s recycling rates could even be some of the best in Europe.He said: “In – we recorded a recycling performance of . per cent, the second highest performance in Wales, and likely one of the highest performance figures in the UK and maybe even the EU. We have achieved this performance due to our change to source segregated kerbside recycling.“I can’t underestimate or over-exaggerate the herculean efforts of our residents, I really do appreciate that. However, about one third of our residents, those living in Penarth, Dinas and the other eastern Vale areas have not yet benefited from these new recycling arrangements and are still co-mingling their materials.”He was speaking during a cabinet meeting on Monday, March , when council bosses approved a new recycling and waste management business plan. Improving recycling rates forms a major part in the council’s decarbonisation plan, called Project Zero.Barry and western parts of the Vale already separate their recycling, with an orange bag for cardboard a white bag for paper a grey caddy for glass bottles and jars a blue bag for plastic, cans and cartons a green caddy for food waste and a green bag for garden waste.The changes were introduced in rural areas in October  and in Barry in October ..removePenarth and Dinas Powys and eastern parts of the Vale still mix recycling into a blue bag. The changes aim to improve the quality of recyclable materials, which is better for the environment and means the council gets a higher income from selling the material. Mixing recycling together can often mean the material is contaminated and unable to be recycled.A -week public consultation will be held in the summer on the new -year recycling plan, before it gets final approval. The changes will likely be introduced in October in Penarth, Dinas Powys, Llandough and Sully.Pembrokeshire has the highest recycling rate in Wales, with . per cent, and Cardf the lowest, with . per cent.Before the changes can be rolled out, work needs to be finished on a new recycling plant in Barry, as the current one in Cowbridge is at full capacity. The new plant is under construction at the Atlantic Trading Estate. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: south korea key rocket launch   days norths icbm test
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe launch came six days after rival North Korea conducted its first intercontinental ballistic missile test since  in an apparent attempt to expand its weapons arsenal and increase pressure on the US amid stalled talks.South Korea’s domestically built solid-propellant rocket was launched from a state-run testing facility in the presence of defence minister Suh Wook and other senior officials, the Defence Ministry said in a statement.It said solid-fuel rockets have simpler structures and are cheaper to develop and manufacture than liquid-fuel rockets. It said solid-fuel rockets also reduce launch times. vw,vw,px, px"The rocket was launched from an undisclosed location The statement said South Korea will soon launch a spy satellite into orbit aboard a solid-fuel rocket.South Korea has no military reconnaissance satellite of its own and depends on US spy satellites to monitor strategic facilities in North Korea.In , South Korea won US consent to use solid fuel for space launch vehicles, a restriction that Washington had previously imposed on its key Asian ally out of concerns that its use could lead to building bigger missiles and trigger a regional arms race.Wednesday’s launch came amid tensions over North Korea’s ICBM launch last Thursday, which broke its own moratorium on big weapons tests and violated multiple UN Security Council resolutions.South Korea’s Defence Ministry concluded earlier this week that North Korea fired the Hwasong- ICBM, rather than the newer, bigger, longer-range Hwasong- that North Korea claimed to have tested.“Coming at a very grave time following North Korea’s lting of the weapons tests moratorium, this successful test-launch of the solid-fuel space launch vehicle is a key milestone in our military’s efforts toa unilateral space-based surveillance system and bolster defence capability,” the South Korean statement said..removeThe rival Koreas remain ided along a heavily fortied border since their ision at the end of the Second World War in .To cope with North Korea’s increasing nuclear threats, South Korea has been building and purchasing powerful conventional missiles, stealth fighter jets and other high-tech weapons systems.But South Korea has no nuclear weapons and is under the protection of the US “nuclear umbrella”, which guarantees a devastating American response in the event of an attack on its ally..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: South Korea in  ukey rocket launch u  u days after North us ICBM test article_url
